rsbNotes.title: Num 22:2–24:25
rsbNotes.text: 22:2–24:25 Though the narrative itself has considerable literary charm (22:28 note), the Balaam incident must also be viewed within the context of God’s covenant relationship with His people. In the vivid portrayal of divine opposition to those who curse His people, God’s faithfulness to the covenant promises made to Abraham is demonstrated (Gen. 12:3 and note). Ironically, the Lord also used the pagan prophet Balaam, who had been hired by the Moabite king to curse God’s people, to bless them instead, and to prophesy the coming of a royal Star out of Jacob—the Messiah Himself—who would triumph over Israel’s enemies (24:17–19).

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:1–9
rsbNotes.text: 24:1–9 Balaam’s third oracle pictures the blessings that God plans for Israel, ending with a curse from the Abrahamic promise against those who curse her (v. 9; Gen. 12:3).

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:4
rsbNotes.text: 24:4 the vision of the Almighty. The word translated “Almighty” (also in v. 16) is the Hebrew word shaddai, a divine name associated with the patriarchal narratives (Gen. 17:1; 28:3; 35:11; 43:14; 48:3; 49:25) that also occurs frequently in Job.

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:7
rsbNotes.text: 24:7 Agag. 1 Samuel 15:32, 33 recounts the death of an Amalekite king who bore this name. Here Balaam may refer to an earlier prominent king of the Amalekites bearing the same personal name. It is also possible that “Agag” was a title, just as the title “Pharaoh” was used by many Egyptian rulers.

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:10–11
rsbNotes.text: 24:10, 11 Balak refuses to pay the hired prophet his “wages of unrighteousness”—the “honor” he was expecting (22:7; 2 Pet. 2:15).

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:15–19
rsbNotes.text: 24:15–19 In his fourth oracle, Balaam predicts the future advent of a royal conqueror who would triumph over Moab and Edom. An initial fulfillment of these predictions is found in 2 Sam. 8:2–14, which describes David’s victory over the Moabites and Edomites. But his accomplishments prefigure the greater conquests of Christ (e.g., Col. 2:15; 1 Cor. 15:25, 26; Rev. 20:10, 14).

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:20–25
rsbNotes.text: 24:20–25 In his final oracles, Balaam predicts the downfall of the other nations in the area.

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:20
rsbNotes.text: 24:20 Amalek. See notes Ex. 17:8, 16.

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:21
rsbNotes.text: 24:21 Kenite. A nomadic tribe of metalworkers found in Palestine from the Patriarchal period onward (Gen. 15:19). Moses’ father-in-law is identified as both a Midianite and a Kenite (Ex. 2:16; Judg. 1:16). The Rechabites of Jer. 35 are thought to be descendants of the Kenites (1 Chr. 2:55; Neh. 3:14).

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:22
rsbNotes.text: 24:22 Asshur. The Assyrians of northern Mesopotamia were already an important military power, but their greatest conquests would be made centuries later (cf. Is. 36).

rsbNotes.title: Num 24:24
rsbNotes.text: 24:24 Kittim. The Hebrew name for Cyprus came to represent the Mediterranean region to the west of Palestine. In Dan. 11:30, this word is used to predict the effects of Roman naval power.

rsbNotes.title: Num 25:1–3
rsbNotes.text:
25:1–3 Fearing to attack the vast throng of Israelites (22:3) and having failed to thwart them by means of Balaam, the Moabites and Midianites (at Balaam’s instigation, 31:16) then sought to subvert and assimilate Israel through idolatry and immorality. When the world cannot eliminate the witness of the elect through direct conflict it often tries to neutralize that witness by absorbing the elect into the world. Old Testament Israel was to survive in physical separation from her neighbors (Lev. 18:24; Deut. 7:3; Josh. 23:12, 13), trusting in God’s promises of land and the Messiah.

This incident at the Baal of Peor was later seen as a prime example of the temptations to which the covenant people were exposed by the surrounding peoples (Deut. 4:3; Josh. 22:17; Ps. 106:28; Hos. 9:10).

rsbNotes.title: Num 25:1
rsbNotes.text: 25:1 Shittim. This Hebrew word identifies the region across the Jordan from Jericho (cf. Josh. 2:1). Here worship of the local fertility god was joined with ritual prostitution (vv. 1–3, 6).

rsbNotes.title: Num 25:3
rsbNotes.text: 25:3 yoked himself to Baal of Peor. In gross defiance of the covenant between the Lord and Israel, the Israelites yoked themselves to the false god through their idolatrous worship.

rsbNotes.title: Num 25:4
rsbNotes.text: 25:4 hang them. See note Deut. 21:22.

rsbNotes.title: Num 25:11
rsbNotes.text: 25:11 Jealous with my jealousy. Note the stress on Phinehas as embodying God’s own zeal for the purity of His people. Such zeal earned Phinehas divine commendation and the promise of a perpetual priesthood (v. 13). Later in Jewish history, Phinehas became a symbol of uncompromising loyalty to God’s law (Ps. 106:30, 31).
